ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ECONOMIC RESTRUCTURING

(Interim measures to help lower income group)

     1.  Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Acting Minister for Manpower what interim measures are in place to help the lower income group, especially the older workers, cope with the economic restructuring taking place in Singapore such as outsourcing and a shift towards the service economy.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Manpower (Mr Hawazi Daipi) (for the Acting Minister for Manpower):  Sir, as our economy

Column: 3141

continues to restructure in response to the changing environment, new jobs will be created that will require new skills. In particular, more jobs will be created in the services sector which will require workers to have service skills.

 

     To help low-wage and less-skilled Singaporeans cope with the changing jobs landscape, the Government has introduced several initiatives under the Workfare programme. The Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) scheme was launched in 2007 to encourage older low-wage workers to work by supplementing their income and improving their retirement savings. So far, about 300,000 workers have received approximately $300 million for work done in 2007.

 

     Another key thrust under Workfare is "Higher Skills for Better Jobs".  The aim is to upgrade the skills of low-wage workers so that they can find higher value-added and better-paying jobs. This is done through expanding the Workforce Skills Qualification system (WSQ), promoting training in employability skills and providing more accessible training funding for workers.

 

     For example, WDA has developed the WSQ Certificate in Generic Manufacturing Skills which trains and certifies a set of portable skills that are applicable across the manufacturing industries. This will allow a retrenched worker to certify his existing manufacturing skills, acquire and certify new skills required to transit to other growing areas in the manufacturing sector, such as aerospace, pharmaceuticals and petrol-chemicals.    

 

     To help Singaporeans move into the services sector, WDA has launched the Certified Service Professionals (CSP) programme to provide training in foundational service skills. This is especially useful for workers with little or

Column: 3142

no experience in the service sector.  Furthermore, workers can also tap on the various WSQ training programmes for specific service industries such as tourism, retail, F&B, healthcare and community and social services. A total of 20,878 workers were trained in 2007 under the various WSQ programmes for services.

 

     We have also worked closely with our tripartite partners, NTUC and SNEF, to introduce the Tripartite Advisory on Responsible Outsourcing Practices, which serves as a useful reference for end-user companies to ensure that the workers employed by their third-party contractors, receive basic employment terms, including CPF contributions and minimum employment benefits.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast):  Three supplementary questions.  My first question is with regard to the Re-employment Act. I am just wondering whether, as it stands, it is sufficient to protect the older workers. There are fears actually among older workers that they might be discriminated against, especially when it comes to the payment of wages.  I would like to have his comments here.

 

     Secondly, I am also wondering how we can actually encourage employers to be more embracing of this older workforce.  To date, are there statistics to show that indeed we have been quite successful in encouraging employers across the board to employ the older employees?

 

     The third question really has got to do with the fact that, given the higher illiteracy of those in this higher age group, how are job creation opportunities and the relevant training programmes that are available being communicated to this group of people?

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, the Re-employment Act will require companies to

Column: 3143

offer jobs to their workers by 2012, once the workers have reached their retirement age. This is promotional effort to encourage companies to do it now.  In fact, through the Tripartite partners, we are trying to encourage companies to start doing it now, even before the Act kicks in. This is a long-term view in helping older workers but, in the meantime, there are schemes that are encouraging companies to employ older workers, including those who may not be employed for a long period of time of, say, six months or longer.

 

     How to encourage older workers to be embraced by companies?  Again, this is done through promotional efforts but, apart from that, we are also encouraging companies through programme like Flexi-Work, to employ older workers and those who have not been employed for some time, through part-time work.  Through this scheme, employers stand to get support of up to $100,000 if they employ workers above 35 and keep them in the job for some time.

 

     How do we communicate to older workers?  There are various means through the mass media, in particular, and through self-help organisations and grassroots organisations.  One big way in encouraging older workers to remain employed and to keep their job, is through the Workfare Income Supplement (WIS).  $300 million dollars has been disbursed to about 300,000 workers. Information has been passed, through grassroots organisations, to encourage those self-employed who have not signed up for WIS to come onboard.  Our long-term view is to encourage workers to work, to have a source of income to support their family and at the same time to protect their long-term interest into their retirement.  And that is why we would like workers to come to work, encourage them to contribute to their Medisave and have some savings in their CPF and Medisave to see through their retirement. 

Column: 3144

We will do whatever is necessary to reach out to more workers in future.

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):   Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask a follow-up question of the Senior Parliamentary Secretary.  On the WIS scheme, would the Ministry review the scheme so as to exclude the overtime and bonus from the computation of $1,500 salary ceiling?  Because including overtime and bonus is actually penalising workers who work hard and it, of course, is a disincentive for low-income and older workers.

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:  Sir, the WIS is a new scheme to replace the old Workfare Bonus Scheme. We said that we will review it in a few years and when it comes, we will take in feedback from MPs and grassroots organisations on what more that can be done, if necessary, to help older low-income workers.

     Mr Speaker:  Mdm Ho, last question.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo:  I want to thank the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for his very comprehensive answer. But I just want to check whether we have statistics to show the extent of participation by employers in the re-employment of the older workforce. I appreciate the range of programmes available. It would seem that if there are employers who are keen to take the older workforce, they can go and apply to the available schemes. Is there any demonstrated effort on the part of MOM to engage employers to really "walk the talk", so to speak.

     Mr Hawazi Daipi:   Sir, yes, together with our tripartite partners, NTUC and SNEF, we reach out to employers to employ older workers, to train their older workers and to even employ older workers and those who have not been working for six months or longer, through part-time work. All these things are meant to help the low-income and low-educated Singaporeans who may need extra

Column: 3145

assistance by both the employers as well as the Government in making sure that they can be financially independent and can look after themselves after their retirement.

EASY ACCESS TO FOREIGN LABOUR IN SERVICE INDUSTRIES


      2.  Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Acting Minister for Manpower whether easy access to foreign labour in service industries is counterproductive to encouraging employers to upgrade the skills of Singaporeans and undermines Government retraining efforts in service industries.

     The Acting Minister for Manpower (Mr Gan Kim Yong):   Sir, Singapore has limited local manpower. Foreign manpower has helped to augment our local workforce and enabled our economy to grow beyond our own indigenous workforce alone can support.  Nevertheless, access to foreign labour is regulated.  This is done through the dependency ratio as well as through the foreign worker levy.  In services, for example, the dependency ratio is 50% with the foreign worker levy up to $450 for unskilled workers.

 

     The presence of  foreign workers does not hamper the training of our workers.  Based on a survey released by MOM last year, the level of employer-supported training has been rising from 2002 to 2006, a period when foreign employment also grew.  In 2006, 72% of private sector establishments provided structured training to their employees, a substantial increase from the 52% in 2002.

 

     As I mentioned in yesterday's reply, the Government has invested heavily in Continuing Education and Training (or CET) programmes to help our local workers to upgrade their skills so that they can take on better jobs.  Under the

Column: 3146

CET Masterplan, we have started by investing an additional $800 million into the Lifelong Learning Endowment Fund this year to ramp up our efforts significantly by expanding the number of good-quality training places in growth sectors.  In 2007, the total number of persons who received training under the Workforce Skills Qualification (WSQ) system was 68,000, more than double the 31,000 persons trained in 2006. More specifically, 21,000 persons were trained in the services sector in areas such as food and beverage, tourism, retail and finance.

     Ms Sylvia Lim (Non-Constituency Member):   Sir, two supplementary questions.  In MOM's recent annual report on wages released in 2008, it was reported that there was wage stagnation for the lowest income earners for the last 10 years and the economists attribute the presence of foreign workers as a downward pressure on residents' wages.  Does the Minister agree with this assessment or that there is a cause-effect in this relationship?

 

     Secondly, in the Institute of Policy Studies Conference in 2007, economists noted that relaxed policies on foreign workers and the immigration have created a new economy where the lower wage workers are losing out. It was stated that large scale import of unskilled labour has its pros and cons and that we should do a detailed study on the cause and benefits of such policies. Is the Government indeed commissioning an independent study into this question? If so, could we have some details? And if not, why not?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:   Sir, let me explain.  Wages of a job depends on several factors. Firstly, it depends on the value of the job, the skills involved, the knowledge content of the job, and it also depends on the productivity of respective workers, the affordability of a company to pay and the performance of the company.  It also

Column: 3147

depends on the supply and demand of workers in the particular industry.

 

     For services, let me give an example, since this question was on services.  In 2007, total wages went up by 5.9% in the overall economy, and services sector wages went up by 6.5%.  And services sector is a sector with a growing number of foreign workers in 2007, and therefore the hypothesis that foreign workers depress wages is a very simplistic conclusion which may not be true.

 

    Secondly, I would also like to share that there were certain segments in our employment market where these sectors tend to have more older people and these sectors include the labourers, cleaners as well as contract workers. And these older workers, in the past, had not been working.  If you look at the employment rate of older workers, aged 55 to 64, the employment rate has improved significantly.  Over the last three years, it went up by nine over percentage points to 56% last year.

 

     With this increase of supply of older workers who generally have a lower education level and lower skill sets, they tend to take on jobs that are easier to do and have lower entry barrier. As a result, the salary would generally be lower. We hope that we will be able to help these new workers to progress and upgrade. We do that through a number of measures. First, we try to engage these workers and reach out to them.  We want to, first, encourage them to work. Therefore we want to provide a relatively easy entry point for these workers to come in and

 

 


we give them the minimum skills so that they can start working and earn a decent income.  After that, we want to find ways to reach out to them, to give them training and upgrading so that they can upgrade to a better job and earn better income.  We also go through job redesign, to help redesign these jobs in the lower wage area – one example is

Column: 3148

the cleaning industry and another is the security industry – to enhance the values of these jobs.  As I mentioned, wages also depend on the value of the job.  And through enhancement and job redesign, we hope that the jobs would be able to pay better.

 

     Finally, even for these lower wage workers, as my Senior Parliamentary Secretary mentioned just now, we also provide Workfare Income Supplement to help them improve their overall takings to support their family income.  We have looked at the wage structure of our employment landscape.  We think that it is more important for us to focus on training and upgrading.  A very important question is, how can we improve our training and upgrading? Continue to press on with our CET, to equip our workers with skills, so that they can continually upgrade themselves and improve their income.

     Mdm Ho Geok Choo:  Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he could update the House on the status of the Train and Place and Place and Train, in particular, with respect to the perception of employers that to recruit our own locals may actually end up in a loss of productive time because of the fact that once the local recruits have entered the workforce, they would have to be sent for training and therefore there is this tendency amongst the employers to go for the foreign workforce.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:   Sir, in the jobs that require skills, even for foreign workers when they arrive, they will still need to take time to be familiar with the environment.  So this does not put our local workers at a disadvantage.  In fact, local workers would have gone through some basic training that we provide through WDA and our various programmes.  So I think it is important for us to continue to emphasise our Place and Train as well as many other programmes. 

Column: 3149

One example that I would like to share is something that we have just recently launched.  It is called the Step-Out Programme.  This is targeted at women at home who have not been working or who have stopped work for some time.  They may not be familiar with the working environment, or they may lack some confidence.  So going through this programme will help build their confidence and be familiar with the working environment so that they also will be aware of opportunities available.  And by doing so, we help to place them into jobs.

     Mr Speaker:  Ms Lim, last question.

     Ms Sylvia Lim:  Sir, the Minister has not answered my second question which was about the call by the economists at the IPS Conference for a detailed study to be done on the pros and cons of our current foreign worker policies, and my question was whether the Government is doing one or considering to do one and, if so, can we have some details.  If not, why not?

     Mr Gan Kim Yong:   Sir, I beg your pardon.  I forgot about the second question.  In fact, the Government has always been monitoring the effect of foreign workers on our overall employment market.  We want to make sure that these foreign workers, while adding flexibility to our labour market, will not create problems for our local employees.  As we can see, over the last few years, during the recession period, there was a significant reduction in the number of foreign workers and that is in response to the economic cycles.  And during the same period, we also see the impact on local employment.  Although the local employment has also come down, the extent is much smaller than the impact on foreign workers.  So to answer Ms Lim's question specifically, there is no need to do an independent study.  In fact,

Column: 3150

the Ministry is monitoring and studying the issue continuously because this is something that we need to respond and react quickly when the market changes.  It is something that we will continue to monitor.

 

Column: 3150

HOME TEAM AND IMMIGRATION AND CHECKPOINTS AUTHORITY


(Shortage of officers)

      3.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs what measures have been taken to address the problem of a severe shortage of officers in the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority.

     4.  Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs how long will the Government's study on Home Team resources take and whether interim measures are being put in place to ease the situation.

     5.  Ms Sylvia Lim asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs how far has the morale of the Home Team been affected by the recent security lapses and what are the implications of this on the security of Singapore.

    The Second Minister for Home Affairs (Mr K Shanmugam) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs):  Sir, with your leave, if I can take Question Nos. 3, 4 and 5 together? 

     Mr Speaker:  Yes.

     Mr Shanmugam:  Sir, on 21st July 2008, I had said that the Ministry of Home Affairs has directed that a human factor study be conducted to look at operational fatigue, and the level of workload and resources within the Home Team. The questions raised by Mdm Halimah and Ms Lim on the morale and resource situation in the Home Team can

Column: 3151

be answered by looking at what the study has found so far.

 

     In July 2008, the Ministry of Home Affairs formed a committee ("Committee") comprising in-house psychologists and scientists to study the human factor situation within the Home Team.

 

     That Committee found that the fundamentals in Home Team are generally sound.  Officers are committed to their work and they believe that they play an important role in keeping Singapore safe and secure.  However, over the years, our officers have had to cope with increased workload, in terms of both sheer volume and complexity in the post-September 11 security climate. While work volume was high, many officers still feel that they can cope adequately with the demands of the work.  But, in some areas, the Committee found that officers felt overstretched, strained and stressed.  Overtime and extra shift work were perpetually required, and officers had to cancel their leave to return to work.  Many even had to give up some of their annual leave to meet the exigencies of service.

 

     The Committee also found that some of the most taxed areas of the Home Team are those that deal with the general public.  Unfortunately, the experience of the officers has been that, from time to time, they encounter extremely demanding, unreasonable or even abusive members of the public as they discharge their duties.

 

      In general, the growths in population and traffic at the checkpoints have outstripped manpower growth in the Home Team.  In some areas, this has taken its toll on our officers.  Apart from the sheer volume increase, the Home Team also had to deal with new areas, such as in casino regulation and counter terrorism; and Terminal 3 and the Budget Terminal have added to the demands.  Security coverage for major events, such

Column: 3152

as the IMF/World Bank Annual Meeting in 2006 and the ASEAN Summit in 2007 has also been very taxing. 

 

     In addition to the increased demands that I have listed, another pressure on manpower in the Home Team is that, in recent years, there have been more resignations due to the economic boom.  Pay in the private sector became more attractive.  However, the 2007 pay review for the civil service has helped to reduce the outflow.

 

     Ms Lim asked about the impact of the security lapses on the morale of the Home Team and the implications on the security of Singapore.  Our officers take pride in their work.  They know that Singaporeans expect high standards of them.  There was disappointment that lapses occurred and a determination and resolve to do better.  But there was also a strongly held view that some of the reactions to the errors were not proportionate.  I had, on 21st July, tried to give a sense of how important it is to view security in its complexity and always in its operating context.  It is important that we be fair to our officers, even as we expect the best from them.

 

      There has been intense scrutiny and at times harsh comments passed on the Home Team.  But our officers are resilient. They remain dedicated to their work and are determined to set things right.  Time and again, Home Team officers have performed well and risen to challenges under pressure.  DPM Wong made an important speech in his recent National Day Observance.  He gave his categorical assurance to Home Team officers that all of us appreciate their situation.  He added that the Ministry will maintain a pragmatic balance and proper perspective when assessing their performance, rather than simply focusing on lapses only.  Our officers have been greatly encouraged to know this.

 

Column: 3153

      Mdm Halimah and Ms Lim asked what is being done to deal with the resource shortage.  So far, we have tried to cope with the increased demands through outsourcing, introducing technological solutions and other such measures.  However, in security work, these cannot be total solutions.  People are at the centre of any security system and we need enough good officers to do the job.

 

     In this regard, we have instructed the Home Team Departments to step up recruitment.  We are also reviewing our employment criteria and job scopes to see if we can accept new sources of manpower in specific areas.  For instance, we have already started re-employing retired officers.  They are experienced and attuned to the needs of the organisation.  If emplaced in the right jobs, they can start contributing straightaway once they are re-employed.

 

     But the fact remains that we will need more resources to cope with the increased demands.  And the Ministry of Home Affairs has discussed this with MOF, and MOF has assured the Ministry of Home Affairs of its full support to ensure that the Home Team has adequate resources to meet these demands.

 

     The Committee of psychologists and scientists has also reviewed behavioural science studies that calibrate appropriate manning levels for various types of operational processes.  The idea is to find the point where our officers feel sufficiently challenged and operate at peak efficiency, without feeling overwhelmed and fatigued.  This is something which we think will be useful and serve as a basis for resource requisition.

 

     The Committee has also done a best practice survey of the measures that can mitigate human errors and recommended

Column: 3154

them to the Home Team Departments.  For instance, many industries, such as the US aviation sector, have a near miss reporting system.  A near miss is an unplanned event that had the potential to go wrong.  Identifying near misses allows problems to be surfaced and improvements to be made early. We are also looking into refining the existing system of "after action reviews" to ensure that mistakes and learning points are transmitted more thoroughly to all the officers on the ground.  The Office of Chief Science and Technology Office in the Ministry of Home Affairs has also embarked on a review of system interfaces to make them more user friendly and compensate for human oversight.

 

     In conclusion, Sir, Home Team officers remain dedicated to the mission of keeping Singapore safe and secure. This is reflected in the sacrifices they have made over the years and continue to make every day.  I am confident they will rise to meet the challenges ahead.

 

     Ms Sylvia Lim:  Sir, the Minister mentioned just now in his answer that attrition among officers has risen due to private market being an alternative career.  Has MHA also done any study on push factors that may have caused the officers to resign and what are the key push factors involved?  Secondly, Sir, in the Minister's response during the Adjournment Motion at the last sitting, he mentioned the number of overtime hours clocked in by the immigration officers and that came as a surprise to most of us because it seemed quite a large number of overtime hours.  Is the Ministry saying that there should actually be a certain number of overtime hours done by the immigration officers and what is the ideal range of overtime hours done or was it something that should have been picked up earlier and perhaps recruitment stepped up earlier?

Column: 3155

     Secondly, as regards the overtime hours that have been put in, to some extent, as I have tried to explain in my earlier answer, this has been caused by the exigency of the situation.  Some of it could have been planned for.  A number of events could not be planned for, for example, our checkpoints are beginning to handle so many passengers, particularly the land checkpoints, that they are probably among the busiest in the world.  And a number of the requirements, for example, the Woodlands Checkpoints, imposed on our officers cannot be planned for because the episodic demand surges.  So it has resulted in our Home Team officers having to be deployed or for us to look carefully at resource allocations to bring officers from the checkpoints which are less busy to the busy areas, and require our officers to do overtime.  That is one of the areas that was studied by the Committee that was set up by the team of psychologists.

     And really which way you go depends on the economic philosophy that you take.  More competition, the consumer of legal services benefits, they have got greater choice.  As Mr Banerjee pointed out, greater variety of services, young lawyers will have more choices.  And if we boil down to the essence of the fears that have been expressed, and do not mistake me, I completely understand the concerns and the fear that underpins some of these concerns, which is really that the parties who will come in will be global giants, very different in size from our large local law firms, would we be able to compete?  It is a fair question but the answer does not and cannot depend only on whether our larger local law firms will face more intense competition.  They undoubtedly will.  And the point is they have to accept the challenge.  We must remember that the decision to liberalise was taken because we believe that it is for the overall economic interest of Singapore.  It should also benefit the legal services sector as a whole. 

 

     Mr Sin Boon Ann raised the possibility of loss of our legal heritage and whether we are pursuing economic interests at any

Column: 3236

cost, even to the detriment of our local legal profession.  Well, I think clarity of terminology is important.  What do we mean by "legal heritage"?  Or what does Mr Sin refer to when he says legal heritage?  Our legal heritage comprises our common law tradition, including the body of local case law, our judiciary, our legal service, our law firms and individual practitioners, who together comprise the Bar.  The changes will not affect large parts of this legal heritage.  They will affect the larger law firms if the larger law firms do not prepare themselves for competition, and it will affect the interests of the more senior partners of the top few law firms.  I have some sympathy as I have said, for the point that has been made, but we have to consider that against the potential benefits to Singapore as a whole. 

 

     Competition can be brutal but can we forever protect our biggest law firms from competition?  That is the question.  Should we do so?  Mr Sin says we need more time.  Now, let us look at amount of time that we have had.  First of all, it has been more or less completely protected up to now and, secondly, in 1999, the signals were sent that we need to start opening up and the joint-law ventures were introduced.  Our law firms, particularly the big ones, have had almost 10 years to deal with the potential opening up. 

 

     In December last year, the proposed liberalisation was announced.  Another year was given.  Licences will only be issued in December this year.  So, those who are competitive and prepared will do well in the new environment.  Those who do not prepare may find it quite challenging to carry on in the same shape and form without making structural changes. 

 

     A further point was made that our local law firms will find it difficult to attract lawyers, young lawyers, because the foreign law firms will pay more and

Column: 3237

will attract them.  Undoubtedly.  But let me ask the reverse question: what is the solution?  Is it to put up barriers to make sure that our local young lawyers have no choice but to work in Singapore law firms?  Can that be a total solution?  From a public policy perspective, when we have to balance the interests of the profession as a whole and Singapore as a whole, including the benefits to the young lawyers, can we put the interests of a few law firms ahead of the interests of the vast majority of younger lawyers?  I am not saying that the few law firms do not have a point.

 

 

As I said, I have some sympathy for the points that are made.  But how long can we continue in a protected environment which, from a non-lawyer's perspective, benefits only a small minority?  Can we do that?  Would that be equitable?  Why should our young lawyers who come out of law school be denied the opportunity to earn two or three times as much as what they might earn in a Singapore law firm and they can improve their skill sets?  In this context, we must remember, because we are talking about legal heritage, that it is important to emphasise that a number of areas would continue to be ringfenced – constitutional and administrative law, conveyancing, criminal law, family law, succession law, trust law for individuals and litigation.

 

      Mr Sin Boon Ann asked how would the provision of seamless service help the foreign institutions, the financial institutions which have asked for this.  But I think the answer is obvious.  First of all, they say that they will benefit, and I assume that they have no vested interest when they make this point.  Secondly, from any market perspective, telling the international financial institutions that whenever they want to deal with law in Singapore, they need to use at least two or three law firms and go to a foreign law firm for international law advice and the

Column: 3238

Singapore law firm for Singapore law advice and pay two sets of bills, as opposed to going to one-stop centre, I think it is a no-brainer.  The real question, as I come back to it, is that our law firms have built to a certain size and have a certain tradition, some of them go back to 100 years. Mr Sin Boon Ann mentioned them, they will face very stiff challenge and if they do not gear up, they may find themselves in a very, very challenging atmosphere.  Should we liberalise and take on those challenges and put our law firms through those challenges?  What are the benefits?  That is a balancing exercise.

 

     I think one can take the view that I have taken.  I grant that some can take the view that Mr Hri Kumar and Mr Sin Boon Ann have expressed.  But after years and years of looking at this, the balancing exercise is now tilted towards liberalisation.

 

      Mr de Souza asked: are we going to stop at five?  Are we going further?  What is the direction?  Let us be clear that the direction has been set.  The speed, the pace of progress, how far we go, how many more licences are issued – those are matters that we must look at carefully.  With experience and, as we work through this, with the initial set of licences, we will proceed at a pace that is comfortable.  Also, in the context of all the issues that have been raised, we are mindful of the impact on the larger local law firms.  It will be a calibrated approach – a limited number of licences, help our firms upgrade themselves, give them a bit more time and, over a period of time, we will see how the market moves.

 

      In this context, Mr Sin Boon Ann mentioned Hong Kong and I think if I am not wrong, Mr Hri Kumar mentioned Hong Kong as well.  Hong Kong may not be the best example because Hong Kong was a colony and the English law firms in Hong Kong could not really be considered foreign.  They had a substantial number of

Column: 3239

benefits.  So, that is not a good example.  Really, we have to look at it ourselves in Singapore and look at what our local law firms have enjoyed up to now and see how much of that can be preserved while we open up to competition.

 

     Mr Banerjee, in contrast to the Members who made these comments, suggested that we should be even more liberal in opening our legal sector so as to attract more legal talent and international law firms to set up in Singapore. These views show that there is a range of opinions that is possible in this area and we have taken a measured approach.  I think it is better for us to proceed cautiously and make sure we get it right.  Also, local and foreign firms need to adjust to the new paradigm, and we will see how it works out.

 

     Mr Alvin Yeo spoke about the importance of the joint law ventures in allowing a local law firm to upgrade itself by partnering with an international law firm.  He hopes that this will be taken into account in the implementation of the EJLV and QFLP schemes.  The Joint Law Venture scheme is an important scheme.  It was introduced in 2000, and I certainly and personally believe that they are an excellent way for local firms to upgrade and acquire new skills.

 

     Mr Sin Boon Ann said that it does not really work in the transfer of technology.  I think it depends on the law firm.  It has worked with some and it has not worked with others.  That is a fair statement.  The issuing of  new QFLP licences does not detract from the EJLV scheme.  They offer an additional mechanism for foreign firms which would not want to go into the joint ventures.  But the importance of the Joint Law Venture scheme explains why we have significantly enhanced it, and these enhancements were explained in my speech.  They are intended to create a more balanced partnership between the local and international law firms in a joint

Column: 3240

venture and it should make the joint law venture arrangement even more attractive and, hopefully, persuade more joint law ventures.  We will take a very proactive approach towards firms that want to structure the EJLV scheme in a way they prefer and, if it is a sensible structure or a workable structure and they want to go further, we will try and play a proactive and positive role. 

 

     Mr Kumar, in the context of speaking about outflow of talent from local law firms, mentioned also the Legal Service and asked what am I going to do about it.  I am not sure whether the question was rhetorical, but the fact is both public and private sectors constantly face the challenge of attracting and retaining talent and, undoubtedly, with this opening up and given that there is already a shortage of lawyers in Singapore, that challenge is going to be quite acute.  The Legal Service has exceptionally bright officers and many of them are young.  It is in this context quite imperative that a lot of attention is paid to attracting, retaining and managing talent within the Legal Service so that the Government gets the kind of advice that the Singapore Government deserves.  The Legal Service officers need to know that there is a clear career path for them and the terms of service in the Legal Service have to be competitive with the private sector, particularly, in the new competitive environment.  And as the Minister for Law, and insofar as it is within my power to do so, this is an issue that I will be very concerned with. 

 

     Dr Teo and Mr Banerjee suggested that it was too onerous to require all complaints to be supported by a statutory declaration.  Mr Banerjee suggested that the Law Society should decide which complaints should be referred to the Inquiry Committee.  Every letter of complaint or misconduct is referred by the Governing Council of the Law Society to the Chairman of the Inquiry Panel.  He

Column: 3241

then appoints a two-man Review Committee, comprising a lawyer and a judicial or legal officer, to serve and decide if the complaint is frivolous, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance, and submits a written report to the Council if it is so found.  The point is, if a complainant believes that he has a legitimate complaint, there is absolutely no reason why he should not put it down by way of a statutory declaration.  That way, everyone's mind gets focused and they know that if they complain, they better get the facts right and make a serious complaint.  It will deter a large number of people who either do not believe in their facts or it does not really matter to them but they just want to file a complaint.  That is the purpose. 

 

     Dr Teo asked why lawyers should be given protection over other professionals, such as doctors, architects and engineers.  I would like to clarify that complaints against professionals in these professions must, in fact, be supported by statutory declarations.  The proposed amendment therefore brings the legal profession in line with these other professions. 

 

     Mr Banerjee made the reverse point which is that statutory declarations should be done away with all these professions, but I think that is a matter of judgement, and as a matter of philosophy, I have explained why we believe that there should be statutory declarations.  To make a statutory declaration is not a very difficult thing.  A complainant needs to only approach one of the Commissioners for Oaths listed on the Law Society's website who will assist him or her to fill in the form, as set out in the First Schedule of the Oaths and Declarations Act.  That is certainly not any more difficult than approaching a lawyer in the first place and getting advice, which the complainant is likely to have done.  And, really, this requirement should be considered against

Column: 3242

the impact of disciplinary proceedings on the lawyer's reputation and livelihood. A complainant who has a genuine complaint is unlikely to be deterred by this requirement. 

 

     I move to the issues raised by Mr Palmer on timelines.  I agree that undue delay in the process is not desirable.  On the other hand, the lawyer himself will want to ensure that a proper process is in place to consider his case.  There has to be due process.  We are dealing with a quasi criminal process that may destroy reputations and livelihoods, sometimes forever.  Justice hurried is justice denied.  A balance has to be struck, and we will try to do that.

 

     The Inquiry Panel will be streamlined.  First, we are reducing from 12 to seven, the minimum of years standing required for the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Inquiry Panel.  This expands the available pool of advocates and solicitors who can be appointed to the Panel and will help to speed up the process.  Second, we are allowing members of the Review Committee who did not dismiss a complaint to be appointed to serve on the Inquiry Panel for that complaint.  Their familiarity with the complaint and the Review Committee's reasoning will help to expedite the inquiry.  Third, we are imposing a number of timelines on the Inquiry Panel for the first time, for example, requiring the Chairman of the Panel to constitute a Review Committee within two weeks of receiving a complaint, and throughout the process, we have imposed timelines.  While we have streamlined the Inquiry process, we have not seen the need to do away with the Inquiry Panel, as suggested by Mr Palmer.  The Inquiry process involves a lay person.  That is important.  We do expect to see significant improvement in the disciplinary process but, over time, if the speed does not improve, we will review the process.

 

Column: 3243

     In this context, let me deal with the point that Mr Low Thia Khiang made.  He said that in 1986, when the amendments were moved by my predecessor, the lay person was for the first time introduced in the Inquiry Committee and the Disciplinary Committee.  He said that was necessary for transparency and for it not to be seen as a fix amongst lawyers, so a lay person was introduced.   He asked if those reasons are no longer valid and that is why we are doing away with the lay person. 

 

     I think he proceeds from a misunderstanding of what is happening with these amendments.  First of all, in the past, there was an Inquiry Committee and a Disciplinary Committee and then the Supreme Court took over.  What is happening, in order to make the complaint go through faster and, therefore, in fact, help the public and the complainant, we are doing away with the Disciplinary Committee stage.  We are having the Inquiry Committee and then moving it straight to the Disciplinary Tribunal.  In the Disciplinary Tribunal, the Chairman and the other members are now appointed by the Chief Justice.  So, it is a very serious process.  It is completely transparent in the sense that the complainant can take part and give evidence, and everything is formal, recorded.  Therefore, after the Inquiry Committee's process, the lawyer, who is subject to the complaint, if it moves further, goes straightaway into the Disciplinary Tribunal process.  In that process, it does not make sense to inject a lay person, partly because they have found, through experience over 20 years, that that really delays proceedings.  Secondly, in such a formalised process, the lawyers would be the best judges.  The Chairman has got to be a retired Judge, Judicial Commissioner or a Senior Counsel and he is appointed by the Chief Justice.  If anyone is unhappy, he can go further.  So the complainant is not shut out.

 

Column: 3244

     Dr Teo asked the rationale on the Disciplinary Tribunal, why there is an introduction of a two-man tribunal, 

 

 

and he himself proposes a three-man tribunal.  What all these comments show is that, whichever route we take, there can be no satisfying everyone.  Some want a bigger panel, others a smaller one.  So, let me try and explain what has been the fundamental driving rationale for us.  It is to:

 

     (1)  ensure that the complainant's complaint gets heard quickly;

 

     (2)  make sure that the hearing takes place with due process and the lawyers' interests are also protected; and

 

     (3)  do it all in a way that does not bring the whole process into disrepute. 

 

     So, that is what we are trying to do.  Members will remember that, in my speech, I pointed out that the original proposal by Justice Rajah's committee was for the tribunal to come down to one-man to make it even faster.  But the Law Society was very unhappy about that and, after long discussions with the Law Society, we decided that we will go with a two-man tribunal.  We believe that a three-man tribunal is likely to face the same problems with the current four-man tribunal where the hearing times effectively doubled over a few years and we do not want to go back to that.  The Law Society understands the importance of making sure that the process is speedily and effectively carried out and has promised that matters would be dealt with in a timely fashion with a two-man tribunal.  But, as I said, we will monitor the situation.  If it appears to reach a stage where it is really unacceptable, we will have to relook at it. 

 

     Dr Teo asked about the remuneration of Disciplinary Tribunal members and he suggested that cost for the tribunal should be shared among the complainants,

Column: 3245

lawyers and the Law Society, and that it should not be from public funds.  Sir, the President of the Disciplinary Tribunal will be a former Judge or Judicial Commissioner or Senior Counsel, as I said.  The second member will be a senior practitioner of 12 years' standing.  These are very senior lawyers in the profession who can command premium rates from their clients.  They will spend time hearing the trial and writing grounds of decision.  That will take a significant amount of time.  What is envisaged is not payment of market rates but a very small honorarium to recognise their professional effort in dealing with the Disciplinary Tribunal proceedings.  Advocates and solicitors are officers of the Supreme Court.  Once the Law Society refers a complaint to the Tribunal, tribunal proceedings are managed by the Supreme Court.  In fact, as I said in answer to Mr Low's point, the Chief Justice appoints the President and the other member.  The complainant and the Law Society are party to the complaint, and asking them to fund the tribunal that hears the case may cause them to consider the issue of cost as a factor in whether to bring or proceed with a complaint, and we certainly do not want that.  There is public interest involved.  As I said, advocates and solicitors are officers of the court and, therefore, it is only sensible that the very small honorarium is paid out of public funds, and this has been discussed with the Supreme Court.

 

     Mr Hri Kumar asked about increased penalties.  He has noted that there is a disparity in the increased maximum penalties the court may award against legal officers who are non-practising solicitors, as opposed to practising solicitors.  He has also made a number of other points about doctors.  I will come to that as well.  I think it is important to view this in the light of the context in which such lawyers practise.  A practising lawyer

Column: 3246

deals with and has direct access to much larger sums of money than legal officers who are non-practising solicitors, especially those involved in corporate practice. 

 

     Mr Hri Kumar mentioned that the upper limit for doctors stands at $10,000 whereas that for lawyers is $100,000.  Mr Kumar has got to go back to the rationale for this.  Again, this was considered by the committee last year.  They proposed $100,000, and I am not sure whether the Ministry of Health has looked at the issue vis-a-vis doctors.  But I am sure, if Mr Kumar raises it with the Ministry of Health, they will look at it and Mr Kumar will be greatly enamouring himself with doctors in the process.  But to be more serious about the point, for lawyers, without cross-disciplinary analysis, this has been looked at in the context of lawyers.  What is appropriate in the context of the amounts that are dealt with by lawyers, in the context of the practice that lawyers carry on?  For example, $100,000 was considered appropriate by the committee, and the Government did not see any reason for taking a different approach.

 

     Mr Kumar also raised the point about why lawyers are subjected to five years' suspension whereas doctors are only subjected to three years' suspension.  The point is that a five-year suspension has always been there in the statute books.  Again, it is something that the legal profession and the Ministry of Law, together with the Law Society, have considered appropriate.  It is the upper limit.  I do not think too many lawyers get suspended for that period of time.  

 

     Dr Teo queried if these amendments were only minor and more was needed to regulate the conduct of lawyers.  In this House, we have heard a variety of views, but I think one point which has consensus amongst everyone except Dr Teo is that this is actually quite a substantial

Column: 3247

amendment.  It is a major step.  It is a paradigm-shifting step.  And the changes relating to the disciplinary process are very substantial.  The whole disciplinary mechanism has been reviewed.  Timelines have been imposed on every step, and parts of the process which have impeded a quick and efficient disposal of the disciplinary process have been removed or streamlined so that it will be seen as effective and responsive. 

 

     Dr Teo mentioned specifically The Straits Times report about six rogue lawyers on the run.  The new Solicitors' Accounts Rules were significantly tightened in 2007.  After the Opening of the Legal Year, the Chief Justice appointed a Judge to chair a working committee to look into the conveyancing system and consulted various stakeholders.  I understand that the committee tendered its report to the Chief Justice.  These issues require careful consideration.  Let us see what they propose.  If more changes are necessary, the Government will not hesitate to make them. 

 

     Ms Ellen Lee has expressed concern over the amendments for medical examination. 

 

     First, let me say that, in moving these amendments, the paramount interest has always been that of the lay client and the general public.  The point really is that the general public must have confidence in the legal profession.  The Law Society's powers come with adequate safeguards.  In cases where the Law Society issues a direction to a solicitor to stop practising until he has submitted himself to a medical examination, the Society is required to make an application to the High Court for an order within seven days.  So, the onus is on the Law Society.  And if it does not do so, its direction lapses as if no application is made.  So, if the Law Society makes a direction against a lawyer, it has to apply within seven days.  If it does not apply, then that is the end of the direction. 

 

Column: 3248

     Second, in deciding on an application of this nature, the High Court Judge has to be satisfied that the solicitor's fitness to practise does indeed appear to have been impaired by reason of his physical or mental condition.  Then, the Judge will order the solicitor to submit to a medical examination.  The registered medical practitioner concerned must also meet such criteria as a Judge may specify in making his determination.  Mr Kumar asked on this point.  The Bill is silent on the specific point whether the Judge appoints or the practitioner can specify because discretion is given to the Judge.  As in the normal way, parties can nominate a medical practitioner for the Judge to approve.  And if he does not feel that that person is appropriate, he can direct the parties to go back and look for someone else, or he can direct a specific medical practitioner.  But by and large, I think these issues will be dealt with as a matter of commonsense.  A medical practitioner of a certain experience and expertise can be specified and, ultimately, the Judge would have final control.

 

     The Judge can have regard to his observations and he can direct the medical practitioner to look at the solicitor.  The doctor can look at the results of any tests he carries out on the solicitor and any facts which are communicated to the medical practitioner by the Attorney-General, the counsel or any other person.  The solicitor is also given rights to ensure that he is given the opportunity to state his case.  There is a provision for him to apply to the Council or the High Court, as the case may be, if he has any proof of a change in circumstances or any good cause for the direction to be rescinded or the court order to be set aside.   In the first place, at the hearing, he can represent himself or get a fellow practitioner to represent and state his case.  It is only when the Judge is satisfied that the process moves further.

 

Column: 3249

     Ms Ellen Lee has raised several practical issues, such as how the medical practitioner would adjudge fitness to practise and whether there is an onus on law firms to inform the Law Society that a lawyer may be mentally impaired.  The issue of fitness to practise would need to be assessed, based on the facts of each case, bearing in mind the type of mental or physical problems the solicitor concerned is facing, and other relevant facts, including the demands on the area of practice.  It is not practical to legislate all of these.  The safeguard here is that it is the courts which will make the determination concerning the solicitor in question, taking into account all relevant facts, including the assessment of the medical practitioner. 

 

     The amendment must be viewed in context.  At present, the Act already allows the Law Society to intervene for various good reasons, such as bankruptcy, abandonment of practice and so forth.  Now, the Law Society can also intervene if a solicitor is incapacitated by illness or accident to such an extent as to be unable to attend to his practice, or if he is found to be of unsound mind.  The proposed amendment is necessary to fill a gap in the range of circumstances and is in sync with the other provisions that are already there. 

 

     At least Members from the legal profession here would know of the 2007 case of Law Society vs Chiong Chin May Selena where the Court of Three Judges had to deal with a lawyer who suffered from manic-depressive psychosis.  Apparently, her condition was known to some others, but the Law Society had no powers to intervene on grounds of mental illness at that time.  Subsequently, she appeared before the Court of Three Judges, accused of breaches of Solicitors' Accounts Rules.  She was suspended from

Column: 3250

practice for a year.  In its judgment, the Court of Three Judges commented that it was timely they considered the amendments for appropriate steps to be taken to examine the fitness of solicitors in sole proprietorships. 

 

     As to whether law firms have the responsibility to inform the Law Society that any solicitor under their employ may be mentally impaired and the attendant issues of liability and obligations, these are practical and indeed ethical issues which the Law Society should work through in consultation with the law firms.  The key concern here is to strike the right balance between protecting the rights of the solicitor concerned and ensuring that the Law Society can deal with situations where the malfeasance of a member of the profession may affect public confidence in the legal profession as a whole.

 

     Mr Hri Kumar asked why a lawyer should be in contempt of court if he should refuse an examination, and he contrasted it with the situation of doctors.  Lawyers are not the same as doctors in this particular context.  A lawyer is an officer of the court and subjected to the discipline of the court.  The courts always have the power to decide who can appear before them, what the framework should be and what the conduct of that lawyer should be.  Therefore, if it appears to a judge that an advocate and solicitor, an officer of the court, is of an unsound mind or requires medical treatment and the doctor refuses, then the judge should have the power to give such a direction.  If the lawyer wishes, I suppose what the lawyer could do is to say, "Look, I will give up my certificate voluntarily.  Would you please consider not making this order against me, in return for which I will not practise?"  The Act does not preclude that.  What we have done is to give a substantial amount of discretion to the judges.

 

Column: 3251

     Mr Sin Boon Ann asked why do we have clause 36 which restricts judicial review.  In fact, he said "ousted" judicial review.  "It is an important constitutional safeguard.  Why are we doing this?"  I would clarify that judicial review is not "ousted".  What we are doing is deferring it, because what has happened in the past is that even before the tribunal proceedings and disciplinary proceedings are over, there were repeated applications for judicial review, which then dragged on and delayed the entire proceedings, vastly contributing to delays.  So, the approach has been to finish with the process, then you go for judiciary review.  Anyway, when you go before the Court of Three Judges, you can raise all

 

 

the arguments that you could have raised during the judicial review. So the lawyer is, to that extent, not in any worse-off position but what he cannot do now is to try and interrupt or delay the ongoing proceedings.

 

     Mr Christopher de Souza asked why allow rule-making and move it away from Parliament.  Sir, this is a very considered decision. The principles have to be debated here and they are all in the Act. What is moved into rule-making is the day-to-day conditions of running a business.  It does not make sense to invite all these law firms, give them a licence, prescribe the conditions, and we cannot pretend that we can today envisage the changing business environment as it moves month-to-month and year-to-year. And when they move, the Attorney-General must have the flexibility to move quickly to deal with the changed circumstances, and, therefore, deal with them as part of the licensed conditions because he is now regulating the conduct of their business that needs a light touch, a flexible touch, and it cannot be done through an Act of Parliament, which may require frequent amendments. That does not make sense and it will not allow them to create the most optimal conditions under which the law firms can operate.

 

Column: 3252

     Mr Sin Boon Ann again asked if we are pursuing economic benefit at any cost. I do not think the answer is we are pursuing economic benefit at any cost. I have already identified the calibrated approach we are taking, and the overall cost benefit analysis, and what goes into the equation. Ultimately, I agree with him that it is a question of judgment. In this case, our judgment happens to be different from his. I will put it that way.

 

     Mr de Souza asked me what is my vision of the legal landscape, going forward. Let me try and summarise it this way. We want our local lawyers in Singapore law firms, in foreign law firms, we want them to be world-class and we want them to get the best training and exposure possible. We would like a vibrant, cosmopolitan legal sector where foreign law firms and Singapore law firms compete on even terms and add to the vibrancy and the potential of our status as an international legal market. We want all of these to create a situation where our economy receives a boost and the kind of support that it deserves from the legal profession, which the professionals and the financial services sector say they are not getting now.

 

      Some of them are getting it and some of them are not getting it, and the whole point is try and move further, to make sure that nothing holds back the growth of this entire sector and making sure, at the same time, that lawyers in our legal profession benefit by increasing their legal and technical expertise by accessing the best knowledge in the world.

 

     Whether or not you accept that vision, contrast that with what would be the case if we do not open up. It will continue to be a protected legal market.  The primary beneficiaries would be a few people. We will prevent our young lawyers from being able to work in

Column: 3253

Singapore for the top law firms in the world and we will continue to receive complaints, whether rightly or wrongly, from international financial institutions that they are not able to access the best legal expertise in Singapore. So, those are the two contrasts.  One is current, it is not a scenario I am painting.  That is the current situation. The scenario is: by making these changes, can we move to this vision?

 

     Sir, I think I have answered all the questions.  But this move should not be seen as being against any particular sector, group or law firm. As I said, and I firmly believe, that if our law firms can compete, they will survive and prosper.

up with foreign firms that offer better pay, better perks, better opportunities, travel or otherwise, and advancement in his career.
